meanings.definition: To bind or compel someone to do something.
meanings.sent1: The teacher will obligate the students to complete their homework on time.
meanings.sent2: Parents often obligate their children to follow household rules.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous elf tried to obligate the cat to wear a tiny hat.
meanings.sent4: The magical spell seemed to obligate the book to float in mid-air.
meanings.sent5: The superhero's duty was to obligate peace among the citizens.

meanings.definition: To make someone feel morally or legally bound to do something.
meanings.sent1: The promise made at the altar will obligate them to love and cherish each other forever.
meanings.sent2: A good leader will obligate their team members to act with honesty and integrity.
meanings.sent3: The talking parrot tried to obligate the dog to share its treats.
meanings.sent4: The ancient oath seemed to obligate the knights to protect the kingdom at all costs.
meanings.sent5: The judge's ruling will obligate the defendant to pay restitution to the victim.

meanings.sent1: The rainy weather will obligate us to bring umbrellas for the picnic.
meanings.sent2: The new law will obligate all citizens to wear seat belts while driving.
meanings.sent3: The picky eater tried to obligate the chef to make a custom dish.
meanings.sent4: The urgent situation will obligate us to act quickly and decisively.
meanings.sent5: The unexpected guest will obligate us to prepare an extra meal.
